====Noun====
[[Image:Stilles Mineralwasser.jpg|thumb|water (1,2)]]
{{en-noun|~}}

# {{senseid|en|Q283}}{{lb|en|uncountable}} A substance (of molecular formula H‚ÇÇO) found at room temperature and pressure as a clear [[liquid]]; it is present naturally as [[rain]], and found in [[river]]s, [[lake]]s and [[sea]]s; its solid form is [[ice]] and its gaseous form is [[steam]].
#: {{ux|en|By the action of electricity, the '''water''' was resolved into its two parts, oxygen and hydrogen.}}
#* {{quote-journal|en|year=2013|month=September-October|author=[http://www.americanscientist.org/authors/detail/katie-l-burke Katie L. Burke]| magazine={{w|American Scientist}}| title=[http://www.americanscientist.org/issues/pub/2013/5/in-the-news-47 In the News]| passage=Oxygen levels on Earth skyrocketed 2.4 billion years ago, when cyanobacteria evolved photosynthesis: the ability to convert '''water''' and carbon dioxide into carbohydrates and waste oxygen using solar energy.}}
## {{lb|en|uncountable|in particular}} The liquid form of this substance: liquid H‚ÇÇO.
##: {{ux|en|May I have a glass of '''water'''?}}
##: {{ux|en|Your plants need more '''water'''.}}
##* '''1835''', Sir {{w|John Ross (Arctic explorer)|John Ross}}, Sir {{w|James Clark Ross}}, ''[http://books.google.com.au/books?id=SdQBAAAAYAAJ Narrative of a Second Voyage in Search of a North-west Passage &hellip;, Volume 1]'', pp.284-5
##*: Towards the following morning, the thermometer fell to 5¬∞; and at daylight, there was not an atom of '''water''' to be seen in any direction.
##* '''2002''', Arthur T. Hubbard, ''Encyclopedia of Surface and Colloid Science'' {{ISBN|0824707966}}, page 4895:
##*: A '''water''' drop placed on the surface of ice can either spread or form a lens depending on the properties of the three phases involved in wetting, i.e., on the properties of the ice, '''water''', and gas phases.
##* {{quote-journal|en|date=2013-05-11|volume=407|issue=8835|page=80|magazine={{w|The Economist}}| title=[http://www.economist.com/news/science-and-technology/21577341-worlds-third-largest-area-ice-about-undergo-systematic The climate of Tibet: Pole-land]| passage=Of all the transitions brought about on the Earth‚Äôs surface by temperature change, the melting of ice into '''water''' is the starkest. It is binary. And for the land beneath, the air above and the life around, it changes everything.}}
##* {{seemoreCites|en}}
## {{lb|en|countable}} A [[serving]] of liquid water.
##* {{quote-book|en|year=2006|author=Lori Foster, Erin McCarthy, Amy Garvey| title=Bad Boys of Summer| isbn=0758209347| page=91| passage=Joe bustled back and offered her a glass of wine but she shook her head. ‚ÄúJust a '''water''', please.‚Äù}}
# {{lb|en|alchemy|philosophy}} The aforementioned liquid, considered one of [[w:Classical_element|the Classical elements]] or basic elements of alchemy.
#: {{ux|en|And God said, Let the '''waters''' under the heaven be gathered together unto one place, and let the dry land appear: and it was so.}}
#: {{ux|en|He showed me the river of living '''water''', sparkling like crystal, flowing from the throne of God.}}
# {{lb|en|uncountable|or|in the plural}} Water in a body; an area of open water.
#*{{RQ:Shakespeare Love's Labour's Lost|V|i|138|2|''Ro≈øa.'' O vain peticioner, beg a greater matter, / Thou now reque≈øts but Moone≈øhine in the '''water'''.}}
#* {{quote-book|en|year=1913|author={{w|Joseph C. Lincoln}}| title=[http://openlibrary.org/works/OL5535161W Mr. Pratt's Patients]| chapter=1| passage='Twas early June, the new grass was flourishing everywheres, the posies in the yard‚Äîpeonies and such‚Äîin full bloom, the sun was shining, and the '''water''' of the bay was blue, with light green streaks where the shoal showed.}}
#* '''2019''', [https://web.archive.org/web/20190311070055/https://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/south-korea-proposes-rain-project-with-china-to-cut-pollution/4819207.html VOA Learning English] (public domain)
#*: The president expressed hope that creating rain over '''waters''' between the countries would help reduce pollution.
#*:: {{audio|en|The president expressed hope that creating rain over waters between the countries would help reduce pollution.ogg|Audio (US)}}
#: {{ux|en|The boat was found within the territorial '''waters'''.}}
#: {{ux|en|These seals are a common sight in the coastal '''waters''' of Chile.}}
# {{lb|en|poetic|archaic|or|dialectal}} A body of water, almost always a river.
#* {{quote-book|en|author=William Allingham (ed.)|year=1865| title=The Ballad Book: a selection of the choicest British ballads| section=William and May Margaret, or the Water of Clyde|passage=But ere he came to Clyde's '''water,''' fu' loud the wind did blaw.}}
#* {{quote-book|en|year=1526| author={{w|William Tyndale}} (tr.)| title=Bible| section={{w|Acts of the Apostles|Acts}} VIII| passage=And as they went on their waye, they cam unto a certayne '''water''', and the gelded man sayde: Se here is water, what shall lett me to be baptised?}}
#* {{quote-book|en|year=|author={{w|Alfred, Lord Tennyson}}| title=Morte D'Arthur| passage=On one side lay the Ocean, and on one / Lay a great '''water,''' and the moon was full.}}

##: {{ux|en|Perrier is the most popular '''water''' in this restaurant.}}
## {{lb|en|countable|often|in the plural}} [[spa|Spa]] water.
##: {{ux|en|Many people visit Bath to take the '''waters'''.}}
## {{lb|en|pharmacy}} A [[solution]] in water of a [[gaseous]] or readily [[volatile]] [[substance]].
##: {{ux|en|ammonia '''water'''}}
## [[urine|Urine]]. {{defdate|from 15th c.}}
##* {{quote-book|en|year=1999|author={{w|George RR Martin}}| title=A Clash of Kings| publisher=Bantam| year_published=2011| page=458| passage=Ser Dunaver's squire Jodge could not hold his '''water''' when he slept.}}
## [[amniotic fluid|Amniotic fluid]]. {{qual|Used only in the plural in the UK but often also in the singular in North America. (The Merriam-Webster Medical Dictionary says "often used in plural; also: [[bag of waters]]".)}}
##: {{ux|en|Before the child is born, the pregnant woman‚Äôs '''water''' breaks. {{qualifier|North America}}}}
##: {{ux|en|Before your child is born, your '''water(s)''' will break. {{qualifier|North America}}}}
##: {{ux|en|Before the child is born, the pregnant woman‚Äôs '''waters''' break. {{qualifier|UK}}}}
## {{lb|en|colloquial|medicine}} Fluids in the body, especially when causing [[swelling]].
##: {{ux|en|He suffers from '''water''' on the knee.}}
# {{lb|en|figuratively|in the plural|or|in the singular}} A state of affairs; conditions; usually with an adjective indicating an adverse condition.
#: {{ux|en|The rough '''waters''' of change will bring about the calm after the storm.}}
# {{lb|en|colloquial|figuratively}} A person's [[intuition]]. <!--is this always in the plural?-->
#: {{ux|en|I know he'll succeed. I feel it in my '''waters'''.}}
# {{lb|en|uncountable|dated|finance}} Excess valuation of securities.
#* {{quote-journal|en|title=Too Much '''Water''' to Suit Cummins| passage=Iowa Governor Will Fight Rock Island Reorganization. He Says That Under the New Plan Too Much '''Water''' Is Put Into the Stock&mdash;Believes Plan Is Out of Harmony with Iowa Laws.| work=The Atlanta Constitution| date=August 2, 1902}}
#* {{quote-journal|en|title=Says Stock ''''Water'''' Didn't Affect Fare|work=New York Times| date=April 11, 1920| passage=the outstanding stock and bond obligations of the company were reduced from $34,000,000 to $24,000,000 by squeezing out the '''water'''.}}
# The [[limpidity]] and [[lustre]] of a precious stone, especially a [[diamond]].
#: {{ux|en|a diamond of the first '''water''' is perfectly pure and transparent}}
#* {{quote-book|en|passage=And when she raised it to see what caused this agitation, she saw nothing‚Äînothing but the vast solitary emerald which Queen Elizabeth had given her. And was that not enough? she asked. It was of the finest '''water'''.|year=1928|author=Virginia Woolf|title=Orlando}}
# A [[wavy]], [[lustrous]] pattern or decoration such as is imparted to [[linen]], [[silk]], [[metal]]s, etc.

===Etymology 2===
From {{inh|en|enm|wateren}}, {{m|enm|watren}}, from {{inh|en|ang|w√¶terian}}, {{m|ang|ƒ°ew√¶terian}}, from {{inh|en|gem-pro|*watr≈çnƒÖ}}, {{m|gem-pro|*watrijanƒÖ}}, from {{der|en|gem-pro|*wat≈çr|t=water}}, from {{der|en|ine-pro|*w√≥drÃ•|t=water}}. Cognate with {{cog|stq|woaterje|t=to water}}, {{cog|fy|wetterje|t=to water}}, {{cog|nl|wateren|t=to water}}, {{cog|nds-de|watern|t=to water}}, {{cog|de|w√§ssern|t=to water}}, {{cog|da|vande|t=to water}}, {{cog|sv|vattna|t=to water}}, {{cog|is|vatna|t=to water}}.

====Verb====
{{en-verb}}
[[Image:To water the coffee tree in dry season.jpg|thumb|right|to water (1)]]

# {{lb|en|transitive}} To pour water into the soil surrounding (plants).
#* {{quote-book|en|year=1900|author=L. Frank Baum|title=The Wonderful Wizard of Oz|chapter=24|passage=Aunt Em had just come out of the house to '''water''' the cabbages when she looked up and saw Dorothy running toward her.}}
# {{lb|en|transitive}} To wet or supply with water; to moisten; to overflow with water; to [[irrigate]].
#* {{RQ:Milton PL|9|passage=tears '''watering''' the ground}}
#* {{rfdatek|en|Longfellow}}
#*: Men whose lives glided on like rivers that '''water''' the woodlands.
# {{senseid|en|to provide with water}} {{lb|en|transitive}} To provide (animals) with water for [[drink]]ing.
#: ''I need to go '''water''' the cattle''.
# {{lb|en|intransitive}} To get or take in water.
#: ''The ship put into port to '''water'''.''
# {{lb|en|transitive|colloquial}} To [[urinate]] onto.
#: ''[[nature calls|Nature called]], so I stepped into the woods and '''watered''' a tree.''
# {{lb|en|transitive}} To [[dilute]].
#: ''Can you '''water''' the whisky, please?''
# {{lb|en|transitive|dated|finance}} To overvalue (securities), especially through deceptive accounting.
#* {{quote-journal|en|title=Calls Rail Holding Companies Threat|work=The Sun| date=April 10, 1930| passage=such agencies would make it possible for the railroads to '''water''' stock and evade the law subjecting security issues to public regulation}}
# {{lb|en|intransitive}} To fill with or secrete water.
#: ''Chopping onions makes my eyes '''water'''.''
#: ''The smell of fried onions makes my mouth '''water'''.''
# {{lb|en|transitive}} To wet and [[calender]], as cloth, so as to impart to it a [[lustrous]] appearance in [[wavy]] lines; to diversify with wavelike lines.
#: ''to '''water''' silk''
